Award.AwardTitle: A Local-Global Engagement Model for STEM Workforce Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Stimulated by the national need to increase the numbers of Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) graduates, this project is providing 28 tuition scholarships per year in STEM fields over a five year period. These scholarships are being divided equally between freshmen and sophomores each year, while priority is being given to students from socioeconomically disadvantaged groups in order to play an enabling role in diversifying and broadening the nation's STEM and technological workforce.

The project is serving to further engage this cohort of students by building on experiences enabled by other sources of support: (1) STEM based faculty mentoring, program structure, and peer-to-peer support throughout their undergraduate years, (2) The Summer Research Institute, a optional skill building campus based research experience for students in their freshmen/sophomore year, and (3) The Global Laboratory, the availability of a 8-10 week participation at a leading research institution abroad while working with an Oswego faculty member and international collaborators on cutting edge research problems.

The PI and co-PIs are sharing the impact of this developmental scholarship model and the results of the program's assessment and evaluation at various regional and national venues including: SUNY Chief Academic Officers Annual Meeting, the Special Interest Group of Computer Science Education (SIGCSE), the Mathematics Association of America (MAA) and the Council on Undergraduate Research (CUR/NCUR).

Institution.Name: SUNY College at Oswego
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project were to award 28 scholarships a year to talented (determined by SAT and High School averages and other criteria) but financially needy (FAFSA EFC < 1000) Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) freshmen and sophomores with a view to retaining them in their STEM disciplines.

Selected students took part in a summer Math Camp a few weeks before their starting semester to strengthen their Math background. We met regularly with students through the course of the year to discuss their academic progress, future plans and advise students of various opportunities available at the College, including tutoring, internships and summer research possibilities available through the College. An important aspect of this was the College's Global Laboratory that enabled students to carry out research at prestigous research institutions abroad.

We carried out a rigorous analysis of the effectiveness of the summer Math Camp and found that participating students had a significantly higher first year grade point average (FYGPA) than their peers. This meant that they were very likely to stay in their STEM major. This has resulted in the College institutionalizing the summer Math Camp and expaning it to cover all STEM freshmen. We worked closely with other grants and offices on campus and over the course of the grant, have noticed that STEM retention (freshmen to sophomore) has gone up from about 50% to about 68%. Some part of this increase is due to the NSF S-STEM grant.

The scholarships were awarded on a semester-by-semester basis. Students were eligible to renew their scholarship depending on satisfactory academic progress and their FAFSA EFC score. Students could hold the scholarships for a maximum of two years. The scholarships were used to reduce students' college bill. Over the course of the grant, we awarded 273 semester scholarships of $2000/semester. Based on the number of students retaining their scholarships from the freshmen to sophomore year, the retention rate amongst this cohort of students was close to 97.5%,considerably higher than the College average. Participating students GPA was 3.2/3.12 compared to college wide averages of 2.72.83 in their freshmen/sophomore years respectively. Roughly 20% of participating students took part in the SUNY Oswego Global Laboratory.

Relevant to the intellectual merit of our Project proposal, these figures suggest that our faculty mentoring, tuition based scholarships and access to research experiences on and off campus were successful in retining students in STEM. Relevant to the broader impact of our proposal, our selection critieria (FAFSA EFC< 1000) and our retention rates suggest strongly that these students have diversified the STEM student cohort at Oswego and that their entry into the STEM workforce has been facilitated.


Last Modified: 08/08/2017
Modified by: Shashi M Kanbur
